segments.source_content: This is [Benedikt](https://twitter.com/bndkt) this week, filling in for SÃ©bastien whoâ€™s taking a newsletter break.

segments.source_content: React 19 is nearing its final release, with the first RC published this week. Apart from this, thereâ€™s not a lot of release activity in the React and React Native communities. So this week, I decided to feature two great pieces of content as headlines in both sections. A seminal 10k-word-long article about Data Fetching Patterns in Single-Page Applications by Juntao Qiu, and a great video overview of all the different ways to build React Native apps with Expo by Simon Grimm.

Hormis cela, l'activitÃ© de publication est plutÃ´t calme dans les communautÃ©s React et React Native. J'ai donc dÃ©cidÃ© de mettre en avant deux excellents contenus comme tÃªtes d'affiche dans chaque section : un article fondateur de 10 000 mots sur les modÃ¨les de rÃ©cupÃ©ration de donnÃ©es dans les applications monopages par Juntao Qiu, et une superbe vue d'ensemble vidÃ©o des diffÃ©rentes mÃ©thodes pour construire des applications React Native avec Expo par Simon Grimm.
translations.en: React 19 approche de sa sortie finale, avec la premiÃ¨re RC publiÃ©e cette semaine. Hormis cela, peu d'activitÃ©s de publication dans les communautÃ©s React et React Native. J'ai donc choisi de mettre en avant deux excellents contenus : un article fondateur de 10 000 mots sur les modÃ¨les de rÃ©cupÃ©ration de donnÃ©es dans les SPA par Juntao Qiu, et une superbe vue d'ensemble vidÃ©o des diffÃ©rentes mÃ©thodes de construction d'apps React Native avec Expo par Simon Grimm.

segments.source_content: I wanted to use this opportunity to let you know that both SÃ©bastien and I put a lot of effort into finding the best content for the React and React Native sections, but Iâ€™m sure there is still great stuff that sometimes goes unnoticed. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re always open to suggestions, so feel free to let us know when you put something out there!

segments.source_content: ğŸ“œ **[Data Fetching Patterns in Single-Page Applications](https://martinfowler.com/articles/data-fetch-spa.html)**

translations.fr: ğŸ“œ **[ModÃ¨les de rÃ©cupÃ©ration de donnÃ©es dans les applications monopages](https://martinfowler.com/articles/data-fetch-spa.html)**
translations.en: ğŸ“œ **[ModÃ¨les de rÃ©cupÃ©ration de donnÃ©es dans les applications monopages](https://martinfowler.com/articles/data-fetch-spa.html)**

segments.source_content: This is a long read (~10k words), but such a great article! The title doesnâ€™t do its justice, because in passing, this covers so much more than just data fetching. Basic React concepts, Suspense, async state handling, code splitting, prefetching, and parallel data fetching to avoid waterfalls. There has been a lot of discussion on X about web app performance in the last few weeks (Rails vs. React, MS Edge decision, â€¦) - this is a great article to freshen up the basics of this topic to build a great user experience!

translations.fr: Une lecture longue (~10k mots), mais un excellent article ! Le titre ne rend pas justice au contenu, car il couvre bien plus que la simple rÃ©cupÃ©ration de donnÃ©es : concepts de base de React, Suspense, gestion d'Ã©tat asynchrone, dÃ©coupage de code, prÃ©-rÃ©cupÃ©ration et rÃ©cupÃ©ration parallÃ¨le pour Ã©viter les cascades. Alors que les performances des applications web font dÃ©bat sur X (Rails vs. React, dÃ©cision MS Edge...), c'est une excellente ressource pour rafraÃ®chir les bases et crÃ©er une expÃ©rience utilisateur optimale !
translations.en: Lecture longue (~10k mots) mais exceptionnelle ! Le titre ne rend pas justice Ã  la richesse du contenu : concepts React de base, Suspense, gestion d'Ã©tat asynchrone, dÃ©coupage de code, prÃ©chargement et rÃ©cupÃ©ration parallÃ¨le pour Ã©viter les cascades. Dans un contexte de dÃ©bats sur les performances web (Rails vs. React, dÃ©cision MS Edge), cet article rafraÃ®chit parfaitement les bases pour une UX optimale !

- ğŸ¦ [Upcoming Spline (3D rendering) and NextJS RSC integration](https://x.com/rauchg/status/1798021886657650711)
- ğŸ“œ [I tried React Compiler today, and guess what â€¦](https://www.developerway.com/posts/i-tried-react-compiler): A super interesting and detailed article about React Compiler and real-world use cases. Seems like weâ€™re not at the point yet where we can just ignore everything about memoization because the Compiler takes care of it, and apart from this conclusion the article is also a great reminder of how memoization works exactly.
- ğŸ“œ [Do you still need Framer Motion?](https://motion.dev/blog/do-you-still-need-framer-motion): The creator of the popular React animation library explains you might not need his library anymore thanks to 5 great new/upcoming CSS features.
- ğŸ“œ [Sneaky React Memory Leaks II: Closures Vs. React Query](https://schiener.io/2024-05-29/react-query-leaks): This follows up on last week's great article. This time it shows how React Query might be affected as well by memory leaks, and how to fix them. Using custom hooks looks like a good general solution to this problem.
- ğŸ“œ [An even faster Microsoft Edge](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2024/05/28/an-even-faster-microsoft-edge/): Microsoft was using React for some elements of the UI in its Edge browser and is now abandoning this approach. See the video linked below for more context.
- ğŸ“œ [Speeding up the JavaScript ecosystem - Server Side JSX](https://marvinh.dev/blog/speeding-up-javascript-ecosystem-part-9/): The JSX runtime of React can lead to many object allocations. Marvin (Preact/Deno) shows it's possible to precompile JSX to improve server rendering of JSX and reduce GC. Maybe React could use that as well?
- ğŸ“œ [Type-safe module mocking in Storybook](https://storybook.js.org/blog/type-safe-module-mocking/): Very elegant way to leverage subpath imports for module mocking.
- ğŸ“œ [Multiple action handlers with Zod in Remix](https://www.jacobparis.com/content/zod-actions-remix): If you target one action endpoint from multiple components, this article shows you how to combine the different Zod schemas via discriminated union.
- ğŸ“œ [Embracing Slow Networks: Improving User Experience](https://www.epicweb.dev/embracing-slow-networks-improving-user-experience)
- ğŸ“œ [Cleaner components with useSuspenseQuery](https://swizec.com/blog/cleaner-components-with-use-suspense-query/) & [Why useSuspenseQuery works](https://swizec.com/blog/why-use-suspense-query-works/)
- ğŸ“œ [Explore new hooks coming up in React 19](https://blog.saeloun.com/2024/06/05/new-hooks-in-react-19/)
- ğŸ“¦ [React 19.0.0-rc.0](https://www.npmjs.com/package/react/v/19.0.0-rc.0): Andrew Clark said "This is the exact build we'll release as 19.0, unless an issue is reported that requires a breaking change."
- ğŸ“¦ [Docusaurus 3.4](https://docusaurus.io/blog/releases/3.4): A new way to centrally manage tags (great for consistency), an experimental hash router (great for offline browsing without a web server), and an option to use namespaces for local storage (useful if youâ€™re deploying multiple instances of Docusaurus on the same domain).
- ğŸ™ [This Month in React, May 2024 - Updates from React Conf](https://www.reactiflux.com/transcripts/tmir-2024-05)

segments.source_content: Many roads lead to Rome, and it seems there are almost as many ways to build an Expo app. This gives us developers a lot of power and freedom, but can also sometimes lead to confusion - not just for beginners! Thankfully, Simon made a great video comparing the different approaches via Expo Go, Expo Prebuild, Xcode, Android Studio, and EAS. This is also a great opportunity to congratulate Expo on reaching [30k stars on GitHub!](https://x.com/expo/status/1796262781584654492)
